course_title: SEM: Law and Social Change in U.S. History
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 12 / Seats Avail: 11Waitlist Total: 0 of 3
course_description:
This seminar will examine the role of social movements in shaping law in U.S. history. Topics will include the U.S. civil rights movement, the movements for womenÂ¿s equality, LGBTQ rights, free speech rights for dissidents, freedom of the press and other topics. It will examine the way lawyers have relied on the history of inequality to argue for legal change, from the landmark Brown v. Board of Education litigation to contemporary uses of history in Supreme Court advocacy. Students will write research papers on a topic in the history of law and social change.
Course requirements: Students will write weekly reaction papers based on the readings and write a research paper of at least 10,000 words (which is approximately 30 pages).
